text:
Hi guys I'm Laura Vitale, on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen, I want to show you
how to make potato gnocchi.

Now, you can make this recipe - I have a recipe
on my website and I have a video here on YouTube

called gnocchi, you can watch it it's me and
my nonna making potato gnocchi which is our

family recipe that I've eaten my whole life,
but did you know that you can make that with
leftover mashed potatoes?

Which is what we are going to do today, because
leftover mashed potatoes that are cold and

dry and I don't like leftover and reheated
mashed potatoes but they make for a delicious
gnocchi.

So that's what we are going to work on today
and the only ingredients you need to make

the dough is your leftover mashed potatoes
and some all purpose flour, and you're also

going to need whatever you're going to dress
it with so I'm going to use my regular good

old marinara sauce and parmesan cheese, you
can use any sauce you like!

The idea is to show you that you can take
mashed potatoes and turn them into something
fabulous like gnocchi.
So, let me show you what I have here.
This is mashed potato, you see this?

This is just a little bit of the stuffing
because when we had our Thanksgiving dinner

which I made a Thanksgiving dinner the other
day just so that I could have all the leftovers

to share with you, but we did enjoy Thanksgiving
dinner a little early, you know some people

use the same spoon to grab the stuffing and
that's fine, but you see how smooth this is,

I use a potato ricer to make my mashed potatoes
because I like them lump-free.

As long as they're really smooth, you are
good to go.

These are really well seasoned, if your potatoes
are not very well seasoned, you're going to

need to add some additional salt here but
I don't need to do that because mine have

plenty, so what I'm going to do is put the
flour on my clean work surface.
Add your mashed potatoes.

If you've ever made potato gnocchi before
then you know what I'm working with, and you
know what I'm doing.

But it's super easy, what you're going to
do is by hand, you're going to just work on

incorporating all of this flour and it looks
like it's never going to work, but it is you

just need to be very patient and just keep
kneading until all of your flour is incorporated.

What I have here is a baking sheet with some
- lined with a lint free kitchen towel and

it is sprinkled with some flour so that it's
ready for the gnocchi, so I'm just going to

keep kneading and mixing, this is going to
take a good four to five minutes, so be patient
and keep kneading until your dough comes together.

This dough is the dough of potato gnocchi
dreams, now this is half, because look I did

already half of them but I wanted to just
show you how beautiful and soft and pliable
it is, so here's what you do.

You take a piece, if you were to round it
up it would be about the size of a golf ball.

Lightly, lightly flour your board, I say lightly
because you don't want to dry out the dough

so much that it gets all crumbly, you don't
want that.

So then what you do is you just sort of roll
it into a three quarter inch rope, you cut

them, don't make them too big, these are a
little bit on the bigger side but that's fine.

Ideally you would use a gnocchi board, but
if you don't have one use the back of a fork,
place your gnocchi on top and roll.
That was not a very good - there we go.
See?
See those ridges?
you need those ridges.

Because that's whats going to help, that's
what's going to help the sauce adhere, so

like I said, ideally you make them a little
bit smaller but you know, patience and me
kinda don't go hand in hand.

But, you want to create those ridges, then
you're going to put them on your baking sheet

that's been lined with a lint free kitchen
towel, you might have to do a couple of baking

sheets because you don't want them to sit
so closely together that they stick.

Then you sprinkle a little flour on top, cover
with another kitchen towel and you let them

sit and dry out for an hour and a half to
two hours, and then you're going to boil them

up and we're going to cook them and they're
going to be so fantastic, just you wait and

they really are just delicious potato gnocchi
made with leftover mashed potato!

So, I'm going to make the whole batch, you
don't have to make the full two pound version

if you only have a little bit of mashed potatoes
left, but they do freeze nicely before cooking,

so at this point, I'm not going to boil all
of them, I'm going to boil half of them and
then freeze the rest for a later date.

So I'm just going to continue to roll them,
see these are a little smaller, see how much
faster and better they come up?

And I'm just going to keep on rocking and
rolling.

My gnocchi have been sitting for a while,
and I just take my towel and I just kind of
mix them around like that.

I've got some boiling water here, and over
here I've got a skillet with some olive oil.

Now these - you don't want to add the entire
thing at once because you could risk them

all sticking together, and they cook within
a minute, if that.

Once they sink to the bottom and then they
float back up, that's how you know they're
ready.

So I just take a spider, terrible word for
it but that's what it's called.

You could use any slotted spoon like this
or a ladle, you just put a bunch in, make

sure your water is well salted, should be
as salty as the Mediterranean, then add them
in.

Once they float, they are ready so I'm just
going to do a couple handfuls at a time and

once they float, I'm going to take those,
put them in here, once I put them in here

I'm going to toss them with the olive oil,

in make sure your water is really nice and
salted.

And they're going to float, I mean you don't

Now by adding them in the oil, it kind of
